THE WORLD BANK Staff Working Paper No. 385 April 1980 THAILAND - CASE STUDY OF AGRICULTURAL INPUT AND OUTPUT PRICING This study of the Thai rural economy examines the nature of the major product and factor markets along with the most important forms of government intervention in these markets. Considerable emphasis is placed on labor, for which the extent of underemployment is found to be grossly exaggerated by current available estimates. This is due in part to inadequate recognition of the fact that non-adult males are drawn into the labor force only in response to peak season demands and that non-agri- cultural employment is substantial. Market and economic returns per unit of land, nominal and effective rates of protection and distortion to the rate of return to land are estimated for 71 different agricultural activities, including 20 different types of rice cultivation. The most important effect of government intervention is clearly seen as the disincentive given to rice and rubber production, due to heavy export taxation. Certain other crops, such as sugarcane, appear to have benefited directly from government protection while all other crops have profited indirectly from depressed rice prices which reduce the supply price of labor and land.  SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS 1. The most important developments in agriculture in the post World War II period have been (a) the rapid growth in cultivated areas and (b) the importance of upland crops relative to rice in this process. Planted area in major crops grew by 20% in the 1950s, 25% in the first half of the 1960s, 20% in the second half of the 1960s, and by 22% in the first half of the 1970s. Maize, kenaf, cassava, rubber, and sugarcane all played important roles in this expansion with most of the output directed to export markets. 2. Regional specialization is a noteworthy characteristic for many crops. In 1974, 76% of all maize production was accounted for by 9 Central Changwats, 92% of all cassava was accounted for by 6 Changwats in the North- east and East, 92% of all kenaf was accounted for by 9 Changwats in the Northeast, and 77% of all sugar cane was accounted for by 6 Changwats in both the East and West areas of the inner Central Plain. 3. Expansion in area planted rather than increases in land productivity has accotunted for most of the post World War II growth in agriculture. This has been accomplished with substantial reduction in forest areas (from 57% of land area in 1963 to 37% in 1974) and there is growing concern about the nature of the 'slash and burn' agriculture underlying such a process. 4. The following are the main conclusions regarding the nature of the resources and sector markets in rural Thailand: (a) Labor (i) Despite widespread acceptance of the rural unemployment- underemployment thesis and widespread use of shadow wage rates well below market wage rates, the supporting empirical evidence is weak. Survey results widely cited as a founda- tion for these hypotheses have been misinterpreted due to inadequate recognition of the high participation rates by youngsters and female members of the households who. are drawn into the labor force in response to peak season demands and due to an inadequate accolxnting for labor utilization in non- agricultural activities. The reports in question in fact show a dynamic response of the labor market to the seasonal swings in demand based on variation in work hours and par- ticipation rates without any significant unemployment. (ii) The most exteasive data on labor utilization in rural Thailand is provided by the Labor Force Surveys carried out by the National Statistical Office twice a year during the peak and slack agricultural periods. Recent changes in the labor force definitions used in these surveys have excluded workers with low hours of work who neither seek additional employment or refrain from doing so because of the belief that work is not available. This has resulted in a large (previously unobserved) contraction in the
 rural labor force in the slack dry season - by some 30% for the economy as a whole with an even greater reduction of almost 50% in the Northeast region of the country in 1974. The 4.3 million reduction in the labor force resulted in a negligible increase in unemployment of some 37 thousand in the slack season of 1974, about a half of which occurred in the Northeast. (iii) The reduction in the dry season rural labor force reflects a very sharp drop in participation by females of all ages and by male teenagers and pre-teenagers. There is very little decline in participation rates for males above 20 years of age. The evidence is consistent with the view that high rates of return to on-farm employment attracts large numbers of household members who are voluntarily out of the labor force in the off peak periods. (iv) There is a sizeable seasonality in work niours. Long work hours are common during the peak seasons with a quarter of tbe total labor force over 11 years of age working over 70 hours a week. Whereas only 7% of the male labor force in 1974 worked less than 30 hours a week in the wet season, around a third of all males recorded such short hours in the dry season. This seasonality is most evident in the Northeast which has both the highest proportions of male and female workers with work weeks over 70 hours in the wet season and with work weeks less than 30 hours in the dry season. (v) Village studies in different regions of the country, when some allowance is made for shorter reference work periods for youngsters and when two weeks a year are treated as holidays, show rural communities in the Central Plain and the North exceed a 40 hour a week norm by over a third while villages in the Northeast fall slightly below the same norm. (vi) The occupational structure of rural employment again reflects the seasonality of agriculture, particularly in the North and Northeast compared to the Central plain where double cropping is more evident or in the South where both the rain pattern differs and dry weather rubber tapping is important in the employment picture. In the North and Northeast, agricultural employment accounted for two thirds of total employment in the dry season in 1974 but expanded by 14 and 20 percentage points, respectively, in the wet season. The expansion of manufacturing and construction in the dry season throughout the country absorbs almost half a million workers relative to a decline in employment in agriculture of some four million.
 (vii) Village studies in the Central Plain, North and Northeast indicate that substantial amounts of work time is accounted for by non-agricultural activities. Representative studies show on-farm agricultural activities account for around two thirds of work hours in the peak season and for around one third of slack season work hours. (viii) Data from the North show that off-farm employment activities are available for farm families without dry season water control and double cropping capability. If the "underemploy- ment because of agricultural slack" thesis had relevance in Thailand, it would certainly imply that underemployment would be concentrated among those farmers with land that will not support high crop intensities. However, observed work hr'rs significantly greater among the single cropping families due to higher off farm employment. Since, as expected, income levels are higher on double cropped farms, this data reflects positive income elasticities of demand for leisure and is in- consistent with the main tenets of the underemployment thesis. (ix) Data on incomes by source also show a substantial irmportance of non-agricultural activities for farm families in Thailand. After accounting for non-cash income comprised mainly of production of agricultural goods for on farm consumption, non-agricultural incomes account on the average for a quarter to a half of total incomes. These high levels of non-agricultural incomes are difficult to reconcile with the view of Thai farmers with severely limited employment opportunities during the slack agricultural periods. (x) While wage income is important to the farm household virtually all year round, wages earned in agricultural activities are only significant in the peak planting and harvesting periods. While these periods stretch for large parts of the year for some crops (i.e., rubber is tapped except when the rains prevent it or low returns discouirage it), farmers are ob- taining significant wage incomes from agricultural activities for only about four months a year in most areas of the country. (xi) The landless rural labor class in Thailand is very small. The 1963 agricultural census recorded 3.9 million farm families of which only 1.5% were without land. Employees in agricultural activities accounted for less than 5% of the agricultural labor force in rural areas of the North and Northeast in the 1970s. A higher rate is found in the more commercialized central plain and in the South but even here employees in rural areas account for only about 10% of the labor force. Since over 99% of the re- mainder are either self-employed farmers or unpaid family workers, the dominance of family labor on family farms is a striking characteristic of the rural sector in most parts of the country.
 (xii) Rural wages vary significantly in Thailand in response to the peaks in agricultural activities and across regions as prospects and/or planting or harvesting periods vary with crops specialized in particular areas. The limited data available on rural wages indicates a general stability in real wages in the 1960s. In areas where crops have done well in the 1970s or where double-cropping has increased, an increase in real wages has occurred. The wage experience in the South in r-dbber areas, in the double-cropped areas of the Central Plain, and in areas where bumper crops or high product prices occurred (as with rice, sugar, tobacco, maize) strongly indicates that a perfectly elastic supply of labor does not characterize significant parts of the rural economy. (xiii) There is considerable evidence of the adoption of more capi- tal intensive techniques of land preparation and less labor intensive planting techiques in areas of the country where labor markets have been particularly tight. (xiv) The evidence on labor utilization, the income generation process, and movement of market wage rates does not support the hypothesis of an accounting wage rate below the market wage rate. The only significant factor suggesting a difference between the accounting and market wage is the nature of dis- tortions in product markets. Since the market prices of important agricultural pi ducts understate the economic value of these commodities due to the effacts of export taxation, the opportunity cost of rural labor is understated and the appropriate accounting price is probably greater rather than lower than the prevailing market wages. However, the lack of determinant resource allocation implications in rea- sonable models in which some indeterminancy in the production pattern occurs means that the such accounting wage rates are indeterminant and estimates must be based on somewhat arbitrary adjustments. However, there has been a noticeable increase in the share of land under rental contracts in each and every region of the country. The area rented has reached significant proportions (15% or above) throughout the Central Plain and in the North. The increase in the lower Central Plain has resulted in a third of the land not being owned by the farmers cultivating it. For the total country, tenancy was minor in 1963 (3.6%) but this share tripled by 1971 (11.9%). (iii) Data on the distribution of land holdings shows little evidence of significant fragmentation of holdings or concentration in large sized farms. Family farms have maintained their dominance in Thai agriculture and the relatively equitable distribution of land holdings in Thailand is remarkable compared to most other less developed countries. (v) Pre World War II irrigation consisted of canals used to direct water over the Central Plains whenever the annual flooding occurred but was not in general capable of affecting the timing of water availability. In the post war period, however, there has been substantial investments in dam systems which have provided water control and double cropping potential. Despite some controversy over the areas actually benefitting from irrigation facilities, it appears that about one-third of cultivated area in the Central Plain, a tenth of the areas in the North and very small areas in the Northeast and the South obtain irrigation benefits. The areas receiving dry season water control are much more limited; less than 10% in the Central Plain, 2.5% in the North, and less than 1% in the Northeast and the South. (vi) Based on projected or under construction irrigation projects, the potential for improved water control can be sketched out for the upcoming decade and a half. The wet season irrigated area for 1990 will be less than 15% of the present cultivated

The projected wet season irrigated area represents 34% of present paddy land compared to 26% in 1975. The following are the main conclusions regarding the nature and effects of government intervention policies affecting the rural economy: (a) The most important form of government intervention has occurred via restricting the rural sector's access to world markets for major agricultural products, mainly via heavy export taxation of rice and of rubber. The sugar cane sector has also been greatly affected through policies which have isolated domestic prices from world price levels; intervention that generally resulted in protectiorn to the sector except for a period of heavy taxation during the mid 1970s. Significant intervention in markets for agricultural inputs occurred between 1968 and 1973 when protection to domestic production led to in- flated prices for nitrogen based fertilizer and through irrigation system which supplies water at zero or near zero cost to farmers. (b) Rice production was taxed at low rates after the removal of the ban on exports in the mid 19th Century until imme- diately following World War II when heavy taxation was introduced via export licensing arrangements, unfavorable exchange rates applied to foreign exchange earnings on rice, and through export license fees and taxes. During the stable 19J5-1966 period, rice taxation was at a rate around 40% of the FOB price which implies a tax of slightly over 80% of the farmgate prices. The period since 1966 has been less stable with two periods of high rice prices in 1966-69 and in 1972-75 leading to higher rates of taxation designed primarily to moderate upward pressure on domestic rice prices. Between 1966 and 1972 and in the post 1975 period, there has been a sharp reduction in rice taxation in the face of depressed world prices in the first period and greater concern for rural interests in the second period. In addition to rice taxation, there have been attempts during high price periods to introduce subsidy programs for low income urban consumers and to introduce price support programs during the post 1975 period. These latter efforts have been small and ineffective. (c) The sugar industry is the one important agricultural sector where government policies have provided protection.
 -vii- and maintained domestic price levels substantially above world price levels through most of the post World War II period. The high level of protection led to com- plete substitution of imports followed by heavy subsi- dies to exports combined with production controls. The booming world sugar market of 1973/74 led to a shift in policy with heavy export taxation. The decline in world market prices in 1976 and 1977 has seen a return to con- trols on the expansion of sugar, complete protection for the domestic market, and low export subsidies. (d) In addition to the heavy protection to sugar, price supports for sugar cane have been introduced at various times. These policies have probably not been very effective since the support price has either been close to the market price or the controls have been widely avoided by setting high transportation charges for the movement of cane from the fields. (e) Government intervention in the rubber sector has been moderate prior to the past decade. In the 1930s, a 7% ad valorem tax was levied on rubber exports, a low level of taxation that was maintained until 1960. A sliding tax schedule based on rubber prices was instituted in 1960. This at first led to substantially higher taxation (about 17%) but this was reduced to around 10% with the lower, prices of the mid-1960s. The latest changes in export taxation occurred in 1967 when the export tax formula was revised and a cess on exports was imposed in. order to finance a rubber replanting project. While the new tax formula implied tax rates only slightly above the historical rates prior to 1973, the taxes have been at average rates of from 15% to almost 20% since then. With competitive market arrangements, a 15-20% tax on the FOB price represents a 25-35% tax on the farmgate price. With good prospects for favorable rubber prices and a tax formula that has a marginal rate of 50%, the rubber sector may well become the most significantly taxed sector in Thai agriculture in coming years. (f) Market intervention in rubber, aside from taxation, occurs through the rubber replanting program. At least 30% of the present rubber area needed to be replanted over the last decade and a half. Due to a rapid increase in replanting in the 1970s, some 36% of this area has been replanted, about 11% of the total area in rubber. This program faces two important problems (a) because a substantial increase in the rate of replanting is required if the backlog of senescent trees are to be cleared before the 1.23 million rai of land planted in the early 1950's requires replanting
 -viii- in the early 1980s and (b) because perhaps as much as 72% of immature rubber in the mid-1970s was based on new plantings of traditional rubber varieties outside the scope of the replanting program. (g) The remarkable expansion that has occurred in maize, kenaf, and cassava has developed with limited direct government intervention. The aggregate farm value of these crops now accounts for 13% of the total value of crops in agriculture, over a quarter of the value of crops other than rice, and over a fifth of the total value of exports. Even less interference has occurred in the oil seeds, other fiber crops, fruits, and vegetable crops. (h) During the period 1968-1973, production of nitrogen based fertilizer was protected by giving a monoploy on the imports of nitrogen based fertilizers to the domestic producer. The main results were: (a) retail prices for nitrogen based fer- tilizers some two thirds above free market prices; (b) limited growth in fertilizer use in Thai agriculture; and (c) a shift of fertilizer imports into mixed or non-nitrogen based fer- tilizers not subject to monopoly control. Price inflating policies have been eliminated and the interference that occurs at the present time involves mainly subsidy programs financed from export taxation on agricultural products. (i) The zero or near zero price charged farmers for water from irrigation facilities in Thailand represents an important subsidy to the agricultural sector. Since there is some correlation between land producing a surplus for off farm sales and the degree of water control, this subsidy is therefore offset to some degree by export taxes on agri- cultural products. (j) A series of summary measures of the distortions in the price structure for the agricultural economy were calcu- lated. The main conclusions based on these calculations are: first, the traditional price discriminations against rice of around 40% of FOB prices results in market returns to land that undervalue the economic returns by some 50-75%; second, the rice distortions lead to market returns to land that are generally around 100-300 baht per rai, substantially below returns observed for other crops or crop combinations; third, aside from some non-traded commodities with prices linked to rice, the only other significant crop with product prices depressed by market interventions is rubber; fourth, significantly protected crops include sugarcane and cotton which benefit from export subsidies and import tariffs re- spectively; fifth, products with low nominal rates of pro- tection have low distortions to the rates of return on land
 and low effective rate of protection - a result mainly of the offsetting effects of the rice price distortions on wage costs and minor levels of protection on chemical and machinery costs; sixth, the incentives on returns to land in the pro- tected crops is substantial, a result explained by the effect of moderate levels of nominal protection being augmented by the impact of rice taxation in depressing the market price of labor. (k) The provision of zero or low cost water supplies represents a significant incentive for crops that are subject to minor price distortions, i.e. most upland and garden crops. While the water subsidy effect is substantial for irrigated rice, this has in the past been minor relative to the disincentive provided by the depressing effect of export taxes on domestic rice prices. (1) The most important effect of government intervention has been the disincentive of rice production and the corresponding stimulus to diversification into other crops due to the heavy export taxation on rice. This taxation has contributed to a decline in Thailand's share of world exports from above one quarter in the immediate post war period to about one tenth in recent years. Around one fifth of Thai rice was typically exported in the early 1960s compared to less than one tenth in the mid-1970s. This movement away from rice specialization would have been even more rapid if not for the continued production of on-farm consumption require- ments of rice by most Thai farmers and the unsuitability of flooded river basins for other crops in important parts of the country. While this diversification has been considered an important benefit of government intervention, this argu- ment is of questionable validity. With their on-farm con- sumption requirements for rice satisfied, farmers become very flexible in seeking out the most profitable cash crops. Rice evaluated at world prices can hold its own against many alternative crop possibilities. It is hard to see why the agricultural sector has benefitted by curtailing the prof- itability of one of the main crop alternatives. This is especially so given that government intervention has occurred in such a way as to transfer substantial resources from the agriculture to the non-agricultural sector. 6. Most of the findings in this study support the argument that market mechanisms have worked well in the Thai rural sector. There are significant cases in infrastructure development, rational use of land resources, and introduction of advanced techniques where there is scope for economically profitable government programs. There is little evidence of market failure outside these areas despite frequently heard calls for expanded intervention in price formation and in marketing channels.
 I. THE RURAL SECTOR IN THAILAND 1.01 Throughout the post World War II period, economic growth in Thailand has compared favorably with most less developed economies. In real terms, growth during the 1960s occurred at a rate of 8% per year and has continued at a rate of 6.5% in the 1970s. Although this progress has been based predominate- ly on a free market economy, government policies have had important effects. This study is concerned with government policies directed at the rural sector of the economy. It is not possible, however, to understand the effects of these policies without first clarifying the main features of the rural eco- nomy, especially with respect to the success or failure of market mechanisms in allocating resources. Considerable effort has therefore been put in,) the study of resources and factor markets in rural Thailand. 1.02 There is no well-established or comprehensive picture of rural labor markets in Thailand. The lack of such an analysis has important implications for both evaluating and de3igning government policy. A common hypothesis is that the rural sector is characterized by large scale unemployment or underem- ployment. This has been used to justify accounting shadow !/ prices of labor that are well below market rates. Since labor is the dominant factor cost in most production processes in rural Thailand, such a failure of labor markets can have major implications aimed at altering market incentives. Net benefits to direct government investments in the rural sector also depends crucially on the nature of employment alternatives open to both project workers and farmers expected to benefit from project outputs such as feeder roads or irrigation water. A major re-evaluation of the evidence on labor markets in rural Thailand has therefore been carried out in Section I (Part A) of this report. 1.03 The nature of land resources and their distribution and utilization is also of importance in evaluating existing government policies and in under- standing the need or potential for new or expanded programs. For instance, production techniques differ substantially for rainfed and water controlled agriculture with important implications for the quantitative effects of the government interventions in product and factor markets studied in Section II. An analysis is therefore carried out on the importance and potential for agricultural growth based on the expansion of rainfed agriculture relative to growth based on an expanded irrigation infrastructure and/or greater use of improved seed varieties and chemical inputs. The response to market incen- tives or government intervention in rural markets, or the need for such inter- vention, can depend on the nature of the distribution of land and the system of land tenure. These questions are also analyzed. This work is reported in Section I (Part B). 1.04 The analysis of government policies towards the agricultural sector carried out in Section II concentrates on the major interventions in product and factor ma-ckets. While there are significant income distributional effects from these policies, it has not been possible to take these into account. Labor in Rural Thailand 1.06 Misconceptions about rural employment and labor market conditions in Thailand are common. The most important of these, as noted above, is the belief that rural unemployment is significant and rural underemployment massive, particularly during the slack agricultural periods in the dry season. Others include the belief that there are very limited non-agricultural and off-farm employment opportunities; that such activities account for small proportions of farm family incomes; that families with land holdings offering limited potential for dry season agriculture are particularly subject to long periods of unemployment or underemployment; that lower farm family incomes observed in the Northeast as compared to, for instance, the North are mostly due to differences in opportunities for non-agricultural or off-farm employment; and that labor shortages with rising wage rates are non-existent. These proposi- tions do not survive careful analysis. 1.07 The labor market in rural Thailand is, on the contrary, particularly tight during peak agricultural seasons with the labor force stretched by drawing youngsters, females from household activities, and workers from non- agricultural jobs into agricultural employment that is characterized by long work hours. In the dry season, the labor force contracts with a large decline in participation by females and youngsters, a shift to off-farm employment by members of farm families and substantial reduction in work hours. Even in the dry season, however, unemployment in rural Thailand is insignificant. Labor utilization is characterized by considerable off-farm and non-agricultural employment that accounts for large parts of money income and smaller but signif- icant shares of total income. Lower income families with more limited farm land resources are able to expand their partic4gation in off-farm employment and to reduce income differentials that would otherwise exist between farm families. Labor shortages and rising wage rates are important phenonmenon in significant areas of the country. 1.08 In this section, the most influential evidence used in supporting the rural underemployment and unemployment thesis is discussed first. The wide range of materials available for Thailand is then used to develop a more realistic description of labor utilization in the rural sector. Farmers incomes and wage rates are then discussed.

Even if there was no such thing as a labor market to allow adjustments in allocating labor time to the point where trade-offs between benefits and costs are reflected in market prices, there may literally not be one person in Thailand who would accept the trade-offs being proposed in much of the accounting price analyses for rural Thailand. 1.31 Apart from the unemployment-underemployment argument the only signif- icant factor leading to adjustment of market wage rates for labor employed in the rural sector in Thailand are the distortions to prices for agricultural outputs. These product price distortions are often highlighted in accounting price analysis, but the implications of this for evaluating the opportunity costs of rural labor is often ignored. Since domestic prices for major agri- cultural products (rice in all parts of the country and rubber in the South) do not reflect the value of output because they neglect the value of resources accruing to the Government from heavy taxation there is an a priori expectation that wage rates reflecting the opportunity cost of labor evaluated at market prices understates the costs of labor. 1.32 One of the great benefits of a properly functioning price system is that the alternative use of resources drawn into a project are irrelevant to the costing of these resources. Market prices reflect the opportunity cost at the margin in all alternative uses. This characteristic does not carry over into an economic system where price interferences result in market prices that over and under state the value to society of outputs in different sectors. Rice evaluated at appropriate accounting prices can hold its own against many alternative crop possibilities. It is hard to see why the agricultural sector has benefited by eliminating one of the main options among potential cash crops. doc.repnme: Thailand : case study of agricultural input and output pricing
doc.abstracts: This study of the Thai rural economy examines the nature of the major product and factor markets along with the most important forms of government intervention in these markets. Considerable emphasis is placed on labor, for which the extent of underemployment is found to be grossly exaggerated by current available estimates. This is due in part to inadequate recognition of the fact that non-adult males are drawn into the labor force only in response to peak season demands and that non-agricultural employment is substantial. Market and economic returns per unit of land, nominal and effective rates of protection and distortion to the rate of return to land are estimated for 71 different agricultural activities, including 20 different types of rice cultivation. The most important effect of government intervention is clearly seen as the disincentive given to rice and rubber production, due to heavy export taxation. Certain other crops, such as sugarcane, appear to have benefitted directly from government protection while all other crops have profited indirectly from depressed rice prices which reduce the supply priceof labor and land.
